Delicate, elegant malt aroma, with a mild biscuity touch. Good body, moderate malt flavor, with a light hint of smoke; correct bitterness. Very pleasant.2006-05-27, bottle, 5-2-6-3-10=26Hazy blond color. The aroma is very ordinary, with a light touch of smoke; the smoke is just more evident in the taste, and there is some also in the aftertaste; the base is a simple beer, quite dry. Absolutely to drink not too cold!

Crystal clear, straw-colored, with a good-sized but quickly disappearing white head. Amazing nose of crisp, grassy noble hops, followed by a light hardwood smokiness. Quite smoky flavor, with a funny mtallic twinge. Seems even to be a hint of that vegetal DME flavor you get in cheaper lagers. Smoke covers that pretty well, but this is not on a par with Schlenkerlas other offerings.
(50cl bottle) Pale straw body topped by medium white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, smoked sausage.  Taste is medium sweet, apple, some grassy, light smoke, caramel.  Crisp light body.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 Apparently they dont use smoked malts in this one, smoke flavor comes just from being made in the same equipment.  Pours a light blonde, with a hint of smoke in the nose.  Its definitely light, you get smoke up front, but its weak.  I think its a great starter if youve never had one of their beers.  Very refreshing, great at a BBQ.
Pours yellow.  Reminds me of a kolsch, but with smoked malts thrown in.  Taste is on the light side.  Interesting, but not as rich as their other smoked beers.

Just a hint of smokiness, somewhat residual.  Clear and pale yellow.  Markedly different from the other Schlenkerlas.  I highly doubt that this would make a good Radler, but it is light and refreshing and made for drinking by the liter-full.

I dont much care for the Helles style, but a pork/bacon flavored Helles is much more to my liking.  This beer had the typical aroma and flavor of a Schlerkerla, though maybe a tad more muted than their other beers.  In short, an ordinary helles with LOTS of smokiness.
Substantive creamy head. Medium body, with cream and grain, smokey and hops in finish as well as metallic. Drinkable, but I thought the smoke was more than I would want next time.

Taster at Binny, Orland Park. A representative was there to explain that does not use smoked malt, but is made using the same equipment thats used for the brewers smoked beers, and this is just picking up the residuals. So yes, it does have a lighter smoke flavor, which seems to be in proportion to its lighter lager malt color. Not half bad, kinda like the Tinkoff rauchbeer I had in Russia (also a lightly smoked pale beer). Gets in a few vanilla notes toward the end. Admittedly, you still have to be ready for smoked beer before youll enjoy this, but it works for me.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2006 1 PINT .9 FL. OZ. bottle: extraordinarily clear, pale yellow with a very thin white film.  Sweet, lemony hops mixed with light smoke and ham hocks move through a very surprising, complex aroma.  The freshness of the hops fits soberly besides the smoked meat.  The smokiness and charred wood comes out even more nicely on the smooth, lightly carbonated lagered palate.  The flavours of this smoked-helles is the most complex see-through beer I have sampledrich, smoky, sweet, bitter and fresh.  Great.

Had I known there was smoke in this I never would have touched it. Pours almost piss yellow with a 1 finger quick fading head. Aroma is of sweet malt,mild honey and some grass. Tastes of sickly sweet malt,grass and smoke. Off balanced. Please sir,may I have a Bud Select?
 Now that I made it half way thru it ended up drainpour. Liquid version of a honey glazed ham. Ech.

500ml. bottle. Clear yellow/gold color with a medium sudsy white head that quickly dissipated.  Sweet malty aroma with light smoke and a bit of grass. Smoke comes out a bit more in the flavor, but is still somewhat subdued. Mildly sweet malts and a crisp, refreshing finish.

I tasted this smoked beer(my first) at the Ale St News diinner the other nite.I sampled some before I tried the salad which was a smoked trout and asparagus salad and I did not like it.However once i had it with the salad it turned out to be ok.The smoked flavor can be overpowering,however on its own.

This smoked has the strongest medicinal flavor of any beer I have ever had.  It really tastes like Calamine lotion smells.  It should also be noted that none of the medicinal characteristics are present in the aroma, which is grassy.  Interesting but not enjoyable.

Im surprised at the lightness of the smoke in this tasty lager.  Compared to the other members of the line, its barely touched.  Nice gold body with a creamy white head.  Sweet bready malts are in the flavor and the nose, and, although milder, its still that good ol bacon & sausage that Ive enjoyed in Heller-Trums other brews.  And its easy going enough to let you drink several in a night.  Or day.  Very good.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL<font size=-1>

Another offering from the Schlenkerla line, and surprise surprise, another stubby bottle adorned with a label in Fraktur German.  After the beer was poured, the body looked clear, pale, and well carbonated.  The head was one finger thick, and left scant lacing.  The smell was only faintly smoky, and would have been hard to place if I did not know the origin.  The taste was more pronounced in terms of smoked flavor, although the pale sweet Pilsner malt and the hint of lemon in the taste were more the primary tastes here.  Unlike other beers from this brewery, the hops were also clearly evident.  Like all the other offerings from this brewery, there was a beer made true to the style under the smoked malt here.  This would have been a good pale lager even if it wasnt faintly smoky.
Sorry. I cant stand smoke beer. That subtle smoke flavor in this one is not over-powering, yet I still had to stop after a bit. Too much. Smoke belongs in fish and meat, not beer.

Clear straw body with moderate carbonation and a sudsy white head. Classic Schlenkerla signature campfire aroma plus notes of pencil shavings, pepper, citrus, and dough. Flavor is not excessively smoky, but somewhat out of sorts for me without the richer, dark malt backing.  Does have some pleasant and creamy pale malt characters.  Good, but not great.  Still provides a nice smoke beer fix.

Draught @ Reading Beer Festival 2006. Pale gold and voluminous head. Slight smoke, grassy hops. Despite smoke and very clean and refreshing lager with a firm but delicate body. Resurgence of smokiness in the finish. Excellent.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2010 On tap at the Reading BF 06. One of the beers of the festival for me. Served to me by Olaf even though they were 3 deep at the bar. What a guy! Attractive pale gold colour with thick white head. Light smokey aroma. Lovely smokey bacon in mouth. Creamy texture. Gorgeous

Draught @ Reading 06: Soft smooth feel. Smokey bacon and salt, gentle oaky peat. Golden with a lovely white head and perfect lace. Brilliant clean malts, lovely light bacon and gently hopped balanced finish. Best pale lager ever?

Rating #1450. From the barrel at Reading BF 2006 (Sunday). Blonde coloured. Sweet and slightly smokey nose. Sweet and malty beer with a nice restrained smoke character that is not at all overpowering. Notes of fruit and seaweed in the background. One of those beers that could be defined as a perfect session beer. Low enough to sip all day, sweet enough to keep you going but not enough to make you feel sick and the smoke character is very well balanced. Very good beer.

500 ml bottle from Stateline Liquors in Elkton, MD (April 2006), cellar temperature pour in a La Chouffe tulip.  No date on the bottle but looked relatively fresh.  It pours incredibly clear, very pale gold with quite a thick, smooth snowy head that diminishes slowly leaving significant fine lacing....the nose at first exhibits that typical Schlenkerla meat-smoked-over-hardwood character, entrancing and sweet, but even with just a couple of minutes in the glass lighter, grass lager characteristics show up, dry hay mingling with applewood and lean bacon, more subtle and less intense than the rest of the brewers work but not much less inviting....in the body, ah thats a premium German lager, no doubt about it, plenty of noble hop presence as clean grassiness up front and increasing in robust bitterness towards the finish, smoky hardwood sweetness and delicately caramelized malts playing a presence as well....carbonation is unsurprisingly fairly low and in this case I think maybe it works against the beer, creating a little stickiness that seems to argue against the heavy finishing bitterness rather than partner with it, and showing transparently a fair amount of metallic character as well (the water, perhaps?)....all in all not quite on a par with the rest of the Schlenkerlas IMHO though it is still drinkable and distinctive enough.

With a fresly baked bread aroma and a hint of smoked wood chips, this brews smoky character is obviously restrained compared to their weizen, urbock and marzens. Mouthfeel is light, but not watery, and while I love the smoked flavor, the finish is a bit lackluster. It ends with a spritz of carbonation, then fades, quickly, into obscurity. I think the smoked character is more pleasing in a more heavy bodied brew. Not bad, but not near the craftsmanship of their other brews.

Available only at the brewery. And in every streetcorner supermarket in the USA, t would seem.  Full golden beer with a small, but nice white head. Very malty nose, definitely smoky despite the non-... Smoked bread-like, if that exists. Smoked but restrained smoked taste (they cannot get rid of it - thank God). Some Pilsner malt obvious but the smokiness keeps the upper hand. Finishes a bit empty, however. As above, the MF is very light - even for a Pilsner. Very surprising lager - of course. But IMO, its rarity wins from its distinctiveness.
pale golden with white head.  slightly smoked flavor and easy drinking.  nice brew.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2007 Pours light golden with a fully receding white head. Aroma of toasted pale malts, hickory smoke, dusty lager yeast, and smoked peat. Taste is bacon, smoke, with some toasted bread to complement. I don’t think the smoke addition complements this type of beer too well. I couldn’t get over the sensation that someone had added liquid smoke to my beer. It didn’t really taste like fake smoke flavor, as the smoke was subtle and not overwhleming. I couldn’t bring myself to enjoy this, even though it is well-made. That’s a shame.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2006 Undated bottle from Belfast Co-op (I would guess it to be a fresh 2006 bottle) consumed on 4/15/06.Full clarity, yet seemingly bottle conditioned?  I dont see any sediment, but the head is full, creamy, rocky and creates plenty of lacing.  Strong retention.  Pure, brilliant gold in color is the body, while the head is slightly off-white.  Either it is bottle conditioned or its just extremely fresh and these guys are incredible at artificially carbonating their bottles.Smells of lightly singed wood, touches of lightly grainy malts and a surprisingly low amount of yeast apparency.  Touch of munich malts in the background perhaps, but its difficult to be sure in light of the smoke.  Extremely clean and flawless.  Light bacon, touch of spicy hops pop up with some moderate caramelized sweetness.Effervescence swiftly carries sweet honey/pils-like malt notes about the palate upon first sip.  Spicy hop notes tickle the sides of the tongue in conjunction with light smoked malt phenols.  A hint of peachy-nectarine and a gentle reprise of soft honey on the end.  I guess this is a smoked pils?  Dosent seem much like a helles, as it would be overattenuated for that style and dosent have the yeast apparency or sourish munich malt notes.  Whatever the hell it is, its absolutely stunningly-well brewed.  Hops linger on, lengthening the spicy nature.  Never a shade of thinning, even upon warming, and though the beer seems filtered, the mouthfeel has just enough residual dextrins to keep things lightly creamy and substantial.  Moderate carbonation, perfect attenuation, smoke is not overdone for the size of the beer.  Hops even seem to grow in flavor as the palate becomes accustomed to the smokiness.  Head never falls below cover, with minor lace down the sides of the glass.  I couldnt help thinking about Russian River Redemption while drinking this one.  Very similar beers (think smoke instead of brett).

Golden body with a moderate, white head.  Mild smoky nose with biscuit malts and mild, crisp hops.  Distant campfire, dry, biscuity malt, grass, light smoked meat, sweet cookies, Noble hop character and a light floral element.  The body is light and crisp and is totally refreshing in the mouth.  The flavor shows the much more subdued smoke element.  The crisp hops and biscuity malts are much more apparent than the non-smoke elements of other Schlenkerla beers.  Its clean, tasty and quite enjoyable.  I need to get some of the more assertive beers from this underappreciated (by me, at least) brewery.

500 ml bottle found at Totowa Wine and Beverage Depot in NJ.  Pours a pale clear golden with a nice fluffy white head, but fades slightly to a thin film.  Aroma is predominantly smokey, but it is not overpowering and a touch of sweet malt and pretty much no hops get through.  The flavor is also dominant in smoke., lightly smoked fish, meats and smoked wood like a campfire, but in the end it gets slightly medicinal.  Very smooth and clean.
Mild smoky aroma, golden colored, big white head, malty, sweet, much lighter smokiness than some of their other beers, very enjoyable.

Pours a clear straw yellow with a lasting white head. Smokey malt aroma but not as powerful as their other beers. The flavor is strong in peat smoked malt but not overpowerfully so. You can actually taste some earthy hops and german malt.

A weak white head topped a pale amber body.  There were pleasant notes of malt in the aroma, a grassy touch, but also a very evident smokiness.  Thin and watery, the flavor was slightly sweet with a bacon essence weaved in.  Interesting, to say the least.

Poured a golden color with a medium sized white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of grains, citrus fruits, toasted dough, and light smoke. Taste of toffee malts, light citrus and smoke, medium bitterness.

Bottle - subtle smokiness in the aroma.  I couldnt stop smelling.  Appearance is nearly that of an AS.  A nice blend of malt, fruit and smoke in the flavor.  I could see an extended session of this brew!

Pours a clear bright, lightly-effervescent golden with a thin-lacing airy white head.  Very nice aroma of lightly sweet pilsner malt and a good amount of smoke, despite there not being any Rauchmalz used in the recipe, balanced with some noble hops.  Body starts with lots of sweet biscuity malt, some lager yeast character and bittering hops before a crisp, dry, lightly smoked finish.  A nice helles.

500 mL bottle.  unassuming blue and white paper label - i like it already.  very pale body with a spritzy white head that lingers but doesnt really do much else.  sweet peaty aroma, i was surprised to find smoke in this one, as i didnt know it was considered a smoked beer beforehand.  much smokier aroma than flavor, as the smoke flavors hide behind a nice fruity malt presence and just a hint of grassy hops.  im surprised this isnt ranked higher than it is.

03.29.06  500ml bottle.  Pale straw color, sort of limp looking with a fleeting, small white head.  Aroma is lovely with a mellow and mild mix of sweet malts, subdued but rich smoke, and distant mineral notes.  The feel is light and lively, and the fine carbonation is completely refreshing.  The flavor is quick, light, and quaffable.  Could be more malty, but I think some of the more subtle malt flavors might be overshadowed by the persistent smoke.  As it warms, the body fills out giving the impression that its maltier than it tastes.  Smoke lingers with more mineral notes, and quick bitterness, almost as if peat smoked.  Ive found my lawnmower beer.  Delicious.

Bottle: Pale straw, amazingly clear, thin white sudsy head falls quickly, spotty lacing, moderate carbonation. &nbsp Fairly strong smoked malt aroma, and really, not much else as it dominates the nose. &nbsp Softer smoked malt on the tongue, with a bit of grassy malts emerging at the finish. &nbsp Helles is not a style I would pick for being smoked. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Lingering smoked malts after the finish. &nbsp Meh, tiz okay but Ill stick with their Bock or Marzen instead.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2006 0.5L bottle purchased from the brewery. Light golden color, very clear, small white head.  The aroma is that delicious smoky aroma from their own rauchmalt.  The flavor is incredible (especially for a helles).  It is a nice, clean helles with that delicious smoky, bacony malt flavor backing it up.  The amazing thing is that no rauchmalt was added to the grist; the flavor and aroma is from their brewing system.  Rauchmalt might not be your cup o tea but we are quite fond of it.  Give it a try if you can get some.  Great beer.

Clear gold, very bright. Small, frothy, white head. Crisp, grainy malt and wood smoked meat in the aroma. Taste like a smokey helles. Light, crisp, subtle sweetness, dry hop finish, wood and smoke throughout. Light, balanced body. Great brew.

What a goodie - thanks so much pivnizub! Fast diminishing head on the straw yellow color. Very light smoke and rose water nose. Wonderful slightly smoked, lavender, grain taste. What a great summer beer. I would love to drink it again.

Light nose, yelllow color, low large-bubble head. Looks and smells average, but the taste is a nice surprise: clear smoke flavor a la Schlenkerla. Not so strong as in their Rauchbier, but a similar type of taste. What a great idea: a light helles with some smokey, peaty flavors. Light body, really smooth.
Clear yellow body with a moderate head. Aroma is smoke dominated with notes of bread. Not as much smoke as its bretheren, but still quite a bit here. My favorite pale yellow lager style beer?

Pale gold body, urine color with a light colored medium body head.  Light smoke accents in a very subtle lager aroma.  Smoke is very evident over a light hop/malt mix.  As per the style, a light bacon flavor is evident.  Smooth ending with some residual bitterness.
Clear yellow color with a thin frothy white head. Light smoked aroma with hints of honey. Light smoked flavor, but easy to drink.

Bottle. Finally this has arrived!!! Pours gold with a small white head. Nose is smoky but restrained. Nice grassy notes, light biscuit, buttery aromas, and mild hoppiness. Taste is smoky as well but its a relaxed smoke profile. Burnt buttered biscuits, light grass or straw, bit of hops, faint lemony citrus, and light meat notes. Body is light and spritzy. Moderate feel with bubbly carbonation. Finishes with a bit more grass and lemon zest, light bready notes, smoked meats and buttery flavors. Very nice!

2.22.05  Looks like Im the the first (or among the first) person to have had this in the US with it being obtained in the US, not brought home from a trip, etc.  I was told it is just being made available around these parts.  Still had the smoky aromas and flavors imparted onto it from running through the system without actually being smoked (or so Im told).  Decent but I prefer the Marzen etc to this.

Very clear smoked nose (smoked like smoked chess, not like fx. whiskey) of barbecue and campfire, hoppy notes as well; Soft with a very fresh sourness to the body, a little thin though; Very nice long fresh malty finish.
Strange beer!
Bottle. Clear yellow colour with a white head. Smoked malty aroma, aroma of smoked sausages. Smoked malty flavor with hops and bacon. Long smoked and little bitter aftertaste.

Pale yellow in colour.  Coriander grass and smoked aromas; bitterish taste with pepper and smoke aromas; bitter finish with pepper and bacon.
A very interesting beer - a smoked helles. It has a good combination of smoked malt and spicy hop flavours. Very full-flavoured for its strength. It doesnt contain any smoked malt in the grist, but picks up its smoky character from the filter. So it really should be classified as a Helles not a smoked beer. Though the beer is unique and really falls into a style of its own.
Clear yellow colour with a foamy white head. smoked malty aroma with a bacon note. Malty, light smoked flavor, again bacon notes and a bitter finish.
(Bottle) Golden coloured with a rich head. The aroma brings smoked ham and sausages. Smoked, malty flavour. I expected more smoke...... but what the hell, I enjoyed it anyway.

(Bottled) Pale golden color with a small head. Slightly sweet, quite smoky aroma. Sweetish, buttery-malty flavor with some smokiness, but not as much as expected. Medium-bodied with quite low carbonation. A pretty nice and balanced brew, which might deserve even more points - but I dunno where to shove them into...

bit malty, bit smoky nose. tasted more smoky but also sweet, malty and a little fruity. lightyellow beer with a very small white head. finishes a bit bitter and more fruity(bit banana, bit citrussy). nice one, easily drinkable, but i like their marzen better.
Bottle. Pale golden colour with a small white head. Straw and smoked aroma and a light sweet smoked taste. Medium body and a smoked finish.

Bottled.
Clear pale yellow coloured with a white head.
Aroma of smoke and wood with notes of malts.
Flavour of malts, smoke, wood and hops.
Hoppy finish.
Light malty nose, with some light smoky notes. Yellow colored with a small white head. Malty flavor, with light notes of smoke. Could use some more smoke.
Clear golden, fluffy disappearing white head. Unobtrusive smoke aroma with a nice balance. Dominating smoke flavor with some hoppy notes. Mild, easy and well balanced. I like it!

A yellow beer with a disappearing white head. The aroma is smoked - reminds me of tared rope. The flavor is sweet and lovely smoked - giving it hints of tared rope, combined with strong notes of wood, leading to a dry end. Nice. Thanks Dalle for getting this.

I am a fan of rauchbiers, so was unsure how this lighter version would stand up to the high quality I expect from Schlenkerla.  Poured golden, from the glass it appeared as a typical pilsener, but when the aromas hit, I knew it was what I expected.  Subtle hints of smoked malt in the nose carried into the modestly malty sweet palate.  Shared with friends, this one garnered high praise from all.  
Unfortunate I havent seen this in the US, thanks to my Brother for bringing this back with him!

(Bottle 50 cl) Clear, pilsener-golden beer with a small, white head. Faint smoked aromas and some sweet malt in the flavour. Weak smoky notes that are rather enticing - because of their lightness. Fresh and surprisingly easy to dring for a "Rauchbier". Brauerei Heller really cannot stay away from smoked malt - no matter what the base beer is. 300605

Bottled: Light yellow colour.Clear. White  head. Light smoked, woody and buttery aroma. Flavour is light hopped and has a balanced light smokyness to it. Is very fullflavoured. Fresh, balanced and easy drinkable. One of the best smoked Ive tried.

(bottle) Clear and pale golden colour with a small foamy white head. Only a hint of smoke in the aroma but a nice malty nose with strong citric elements. Slight taste of smoked bacon with malts and a dry well rounded smooth dry slightly bitter finish. I wish this one could be my everyday beer for the summer of 2005 !

A big thanks to Skidz, my roommate and Beer Advocate, for bringing this and other tasty beers back with him from Germany!  Im drinking this with burgers and brats on the grill, as it should be the perfect beer to compliment grilled meats on a very humid June day...  Pours a crystal clear bright gold with a big, bright white head.  Aroma is (of course) smokey, bringing to mind fried breakfast sausage and almonds, complimented by a light flowery smell and some woodiness.  Taste is smoked nuts, mild citrus, cooked cereal  and some hops thrown in to boot.  Surprisingly refreshing for a smoked beer, partly due to a rather mild smoke presence.

Bottle (bought at Vronis in Bamberg):Straw golden colour, thin head; fruity, grainy nose with a subtle tinge of smoke; fruity (citrus) beginning, fruity and malty flavour leading to a dry, smoky ending; astonishingly fresh for a smoked beer, the contrast between the fruity notes and the smoke creates a very complex brew. Beautiful......

Bottle.  Smoked ham aroma - more subtle than the Marzen.  Golden  yellow color with next to no head.   Wood smoke flavor a bit like smoked ham - again much less intense than the Marzen.  This is a much easier drinking beer - lighter but full flavored.
Bottle. Golden with a bubbly white head. Cereal-maltiness, light smoke, wee bit of grass and citrus, dry-ish finish. Medium-full body, above avg. carbonation. Nice lager.
First to get jused to the smoky smell and taste. You must really liked this beerstyle.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2009 Clean golden coloured, thin lacing. Smells like a classic german pilsener, but then of course with the excellent smoked malts this brewery is famous for. Very smooth smoky flavour. Not as heavy as its brothers, but nicely balanced and very easy to drink.
I dont like this beer. Smoked.. the taste is like, well.. not good. Bitter aftertaste.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2011 Bottle at Evening Star Brighton.  There was absolutely no signs of smokiness in either the aroma or taste of this beer (unfortunately).  The smell was like a Marzen and the colour was virtually clear.  The taste was however better being clean and dry.  I like smoked beers a lot and struggle to see that this bottle did the brewery justification.  Score 2.6Subsequent rating scored 3.8. Average becomes 3.2
Clear yellow color, medium white head. Aroma of weak smoke, bacon, hops. Soft pilsener taste with some smoked notes. Bitter bacon aftertaste.
Aroma is smoked, bacon, hoppy, some malts and smooth. taste is smoked bacon, hoppy, a little sweet, some malts, quite bitter with a lasting smooth aftertaste. Well-brewed.

Very smoky (duh).  Really reminds me of barbeque, mesquite or something.  Being that I generally associated these scents/flavors with barbequing stuff, this beer smells like meat to me.  I'll add that I really, really like barbeque, though that's not particularly relevant.  But what is relevant in the long run?  I mean, on a cosmic scale, even the deepest concepts are . . . wait, I've wandered.  Back to the review.  Reminds me quite a bit of Rogue's Mexicali Ale, just missing the slight smoked chili aspect of that one.  Has the same nice, creamy texture.  Quite malty.  Was really taken aback by the nose at first, but a surprisingly enjoyable brew.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2008 Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly diminishing. Body is clear medium yellow. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted bread), lightly to moderately hoppy (flowers, herbs), with notes of smoke and honey. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. A simple beer, but very clean and succulent.  Lovely aroma where malt, hops, and the smokiness all play equal roles.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2004 Bottle from the Swan and Rushes. Very disappointing stuff. Bland aroma: hammy lager, sweet and salty. This tastes like normal lager with a bit of ham. The flavour is not full and there is little development - in fact it's not at all complex. Some tingle on the tongue and a dry finish, but not too much out of the ordinary, only a little extra taste to a normal ' bad' lager. Disappointing from such a good brewer.
My bottle was called "Schlenkerla Helles Lager". Malty aroma. Long bitter finish. Not very smoked. Low carbonation.

Bottled Schlenkerla, Bamberg, Germany. 4.3 ABV. First I thought this beer was another, but apparently it's not. However I do not agree that this is a smoked beer, mine was'nt. That is why I think it is interesting to see a lager beer with no smoke taste from Schlenkerla. Rare and special.
Nobbad, quite enjoyed it. Lightly smoked, bacon flavour, dry-ish, slightly herbal hops finish, a bit salty (Draught- GBBF 03')
Gravity Cask, GBBF   Butter, grass and fine rain. Clean taste which resembles aroma. Creamy initial finish which then bursts with woody bitterness and a touch of band aid.

A representative of Celebrator Beer News at the bar said that seeing this beer on cask was a rare treat, so I bought a half-pint.  Light yellow, perfectly clear.  Slight head with slow moving bubbles in the body.  Dry grassiness, hay--is it Saaz?--flavor suggests popcorn butter.  Didn't find much smokiness.  Unexceptional to my taste-buds. (gravity pour at GBBF 2003)

Wooden cask (gravity) GBBF2003. Gold, good white head and moderate condition. No apparent smokiness in the aroma, just a suggestion of fields full of cow dung. Good helles type sweet malt in the mouth and a lingering grainy aftertaste.
Yellow beer with an aroma rather like a very poor Russian lager.  Deep bitter finish from this weak lager.  Overall not that pleasant.

Smoked malt nose complemented by grassy hops.
Straw golden, light carbonation, fine white head. 
Rich taste where malt, smoke and dry bitterhop taste complement each other beautifully.
Medium body with a light refreshing aftertaste.
The fat palate effectively hides  the low abv.
Strong smokey aroma. Typical smoked ham flavor. Hoppy and absolutely dry with a hint of maltiness and some hidden fruitiness. Long burnt wood finish. A classic!
Bottled. Pale yellow. Smoked sausage aroma. Light bodied, but with dense malty mouthfeel. Nearly as smokey as the other Schlenkerlas.
very light and meek lager, with bacon all over it. strange combination - not as strong tasting as the spezial rauchlager. easy-drinkin rauchbier
bacon juice aroma overwhelmed my tastebuds. not sure why it is lower alcohol. the lady at the brewery seemed very surprised anyone would ask for this

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2009 Clear yellow.  Thin head.  Aroma of pale malts with maybe some light fruity hop.  Fairly bland palate.  Maybe some light apple and vague malts.  Pretty lame beer, albeit intentionally.
